Award.AwardTitle: Instabilities, asymptotic isometry, and energy condensation in elastic sheets under twist
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Abstract
The goal of the project is to develop a deep understanding of how thin elastic materials undergo buckling and creasing when subjected to twist. This knowledge is essential in obtaining the maximum functionality from devices made with new materials such as graphene sheets, nanotubes, semiconductor nanoribbons, and various biomaterials. Theoretical understanding of how thin sheets buckle and crease under stress is just in its infancy and these experimental studies will provide both guidance to and tests of these theories. Ultimately, this research will impact determination of strength and failure of thin materials under stress, and manufacturing of flexible structures and yarns by developing widely scalable techniques to pattern slender materials. The proposed research will also have a significant impact on educating students pursuing careers in STEM related disciplines. The dissertation research work of graduate students will be impacted by the grant. The project will enhance research experience of undergraduate students in the laboratory.

Technical Paragraph
The goal of the project is to understand the buckling instabilities of thin elastic sheets subjected to twist which lead to wrinkling, stress focusing and energy condensation into creased structures. The fundamental role of elasticity and geometry in organizing the shape of the post-buckled structures will be investigated with experiments which will measure the shapes of the structures using micro x-ray tomography techniques and laser-aided optical imaging techniques. The phase diagram anticipated by a newly developed co-variant form of the Foppl-von Karman equations for thin plates will be investigated as function of sheet aspect ratio and elastic modulus. Development of minimal ridge structures and their interactions observed during the twisting of thin ribbon shapes will be used to study the scaling of the associated energy as a function of sheet thickness and applied deformation. Understanding formation of self-scrolled yarn and fabric structures under twist will provide an alternate reliable and efficient strategy to build mesoscale hierarchical structures with novel materials including graphene sheets, nanotubes, semiconductor nanoribbons, and biomaterials. Peer reviewed scientific publications will increase scientific knowledge in the field of condensed matter physics and will be disseminated on the web. Undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in the field of elasticity and soft matter, and in using sophisticated imaging techniques and analysis towards careers in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigated the shape and deformation of thin elastic solids as a function of their physical dimensions and material properties using advanced micro-focus x-ray and optical measurement techniques, and with complementary elastomechanical analysis. The focus was to develop data-tested elastomechanical models to predict how materials, in the form of thin rods, ribbons and sheets, can buckle and fail as a function of applied loading. It is generally thought that a material can fail at and along point and line defects or due to other inhomogeneities present in the manufacturing process.  We examined how, even, perfectly-made, completely uniform materials can develop defects due to stress focusing, which occurs as a function of loading protocols.

We examined the deformation when a thin elastic sheet is stressed under tension and twisted in a regime where the covariant form of the Foppl von Karman equations were developed in response to our preliminary work on twisted ribbons. The exact method by which boundary conditions were administered were found to have an impact on the failure mode. While the sheet deforms helicoidally initially, we find that the sheet can buckle in two distinct modes depending on the applied tension and the aspect ratio of the sheet. Our study conducted a thorough test of the scaling provided by far-from-threshold models and the regimes of their applicability, as opposed to direct numerical simulations of the thin plate equations. Those alternate numerical approaches, while accurate, give rise to less insight on the development of the instabilities, and the various operative mechanisms. Our approach also yields simple forms for the dependence on material parameters which other researchers can apply to their problems.  Our work highlighted the differences in laboratory materials in relation to idealized models which assume that elastic materials only bend, and do not stretch, in the ultra-thin limit. The effect of the environment and presence of filler materials on the response under external loading in the form of viscous dissipation and magnetically applied torques was also accomplished. Our work addresses challenges encountered in the manufacture of functional materials including flexible electronics and biomaterials.  

We published peer-reviewed articles in scientific journals published by the American Physical Society and the Royal Society of Chemistry, reporting our systematic measurements of the onset of transverse and longitudinal buckling instabilities. We further investigated the effect of many filament interactions with detailed x-ray tomography measurements, and non-Euclidian geometric analysis. Copies of these reports where also posted on preprint servers and on the laboratory web pages where anyone with an internet connection can download a copy for free. The results of our studies were also reported at the scientific meetings of the American Physical Society to inform experts on our progress, and at colloquiums open to the public at colleges and universities. Video recordings were also made available freely online.

Postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate students participated in the project activities, and received training in doing research and development in condensed matter physics, and laboratory automation methods, and data analysis. These are highly portable skills that they can apply across STEM fields as their careers progress further. The grant activity also fostered collaborations between researchers at Clark University, and experts in soft matter physics at Universidade Federal da Bahia (UFBA) in Brazil, UMass Amherst, and Harvard University. Outreach activities involving demonstrations based on physical phenomena including optics, electricity, magnetism and elasticity, were also made at Cambridge Science Days, and Latino Science and Robotics Day events to reach K-12 students, and spark their interest in Science.
